awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Programmable Chip-Scale Quantum-Photonics Platform Based on Frequency-Comb Cluster-States for Multicasting Quantum Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
The field of quantum information science and technology hinges on unique quantum mechanical phenomena such as entanglement to enable unprecedented capabilities for communication, sensing, and computing. Among these technologies, quantum communication is foreseen to create broad near-term impacts as seen in recent quantum testbeds, teleportation, and entanglement distribution experiments. It is also envisaged to underpin future's fully connected quantum computers, quantum sensors, and a global secure communication network. Mainstream quantum communication platforms, however, rely on expensive, unscalable bulk optics components that impede their widespread deployment. While recent work on integrated quantum communication devices opens a new route to the development of compact quantum-communication systems, an integrated quantum photonics platform encompassing multiple, functional modules on a single chip to generate and process large-scale entanglement remains elusive. 
This collaborative project will develop a room-temperature integrated quantum photonics platform that incorporates quantum communication modules for scalable generation, processing, multicasting, and detection of large-scale multipartite entanglement in a quantum communication network. This project will leverage the nanofabrication and testing expertise at UCLA and the Interdisciplinary Quantum Information Research and Engineering (INQUIRE) testbed at the University of Arizona (UA) to demonstrate the capability of utilizing a highly compact and mass producible integrated platform to generate, multicast, and detect large-scale entanglement in a real-world setting. The outcome of the project will lay the foundation for future's quantum internet comprised of compact devices linked by large-scale multipartite entanglement. This project will educate and train the next-generation workforce for quantum information science and technology. Specifically, undergraduate and graduate students will grasp essential knowledge and expertise of nanophotonics and quantum information science and technology. They will gain hands-on experience while undertaking research in the INQUIRE testbed. This project will also provide opportunities for various industrial partners to be exposed to state-of-the-art tools grown out of nanophotonics and quantum information science and technology.

Technical: The team will follow a system-level design approach for the integrated quantum photonics platform. The project will advance knowledge through a new quantum encoding-and-decoding paradigm that will be seamlessly incorporated into a physical architecture to offer intrinsic protection against loss. The physical architecture will consist of programmable quantum sources, processing units, and receivers using the silicon nitride material system that offer dramatic functionalities. Through ��(3 four-wave mixing in microring resonators and Mach-Zehnder interferometers, the silicon nitride chipset section will produce and process quantum signals with high fidelity and low loss. The silicon nitride section will also provide a classical frequency comb to serve as the pump for the microring resonators and phase references for the Mach-Zehnder interferometers. Programming of the quantum sources, processing units, and receivers will be by modulating the classical comb spectral lines in an integrated hybrid silicon section. In our frequency comb cluster system, the quantum signals will be immune to the programming-induced loss and disturbance. The integrated quantum photonics platform will be programmed to support two system-level quantum communication implementations: 1) a high-rate secure communication system based on quantum illumination; and 2) an entanglement multicasting and purification demonstration.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has pushed the boundaries of quantum science and technology by developing a novel approach to generating and controlling quantum light on a chip. The work has not only advanced fundamental understanding in quantum optics but also laid the groundwork for real-world applications in secure communications, advanced sensing, and next-generation computing.

Key Scientific and Technological Achievements
Over the course of the award, our team established a comprehensive theoretical framework for producing large-scale entangled quantum states using silicon nitride—a material that supports mass production. This theory enabled us to design integrated photonic circuits capable of generating nonclassical light, an essential ingredient for quantum technologies. In the early stages, we focused on perfecting the design of on-chip photonic structures such as microring resonators and waveguides. Later, we developed innovative fabrication recipes to create high-quality, crack-free silicon nitride films and integrated quantum photonic components with record-setting performance metrics. Notably, we demonstrated a measured 3 dB of squeezed light (with an inference of over 8 dB on-chip), a key milestone toward scalable quantum information processing.

Our team also made significant strides in refining nanofabrication techniques. We optimized processes including electron-beam lithography and nanoimprint lithography, achieving ultra-low-loss devices with high intrinsic quality factors. These advancements ensure that our integrated photonic chips not only generate high-quality quantum states but are also robust and reproducible, making them suitable for industrial-scale manufacturing. Collaborative efforts, including a partnership with Honeywell, extended our capabilities to foundry-scale production, further accelerating the transition from laboratory research to practical applications.

Throughout the project, our team devised and implemented multiple entanglement-enhanced protocols for communication, sensing, and information processing. Notably, we demonstrated entanglement-assisted communication at a rate surpassing the ultimate classical limit, quantum-secured covert sensing endowing performance, security, and data integrity, and more recently entangled dual-comb spectroscopy for precise detection of gas samples for a variety of biochemical sensing, environment monitoring, and homeland security applications.

Broader Impacts and Societal Benefits
Beyond the scientific breakthroughs, this project has had a wide-ranging impact on education, workforce development, and technology transfer. Graduate and undergraduate students, as well as senior researchers, received hands-on training in quantum photonics, nanofabrication, and advanced measurement techniques. This experience has equipped them with cutting-edge skills that are directly applicable to emerging fields in quantum technology and semiconductor manufacturing.

The research has also been disseminated through numerous high-impact journal publications, conference presentations, and public outreach events. These efforts have raised awareness of quantum information science among both academic and general audiences, inspiring the next generation of scientists and engineers. The development of integrated quantum photonic circuits and advanced fabrication protocols not only contributes to the academic community but also offers promising applications in telecommunications, remote sensing, and secure communication systems—areas that are critical to national security and economic growth.

Furthermore, several provisional patents have been filed based on the novel techniques and devices developed during the project, highlighting its potential for technology transfer and commercialization. This work is expected to stimulate further research and collaboration among academic institutions, industry partners, and government agencies, accelerating the deployment of quantum technologies in real-world settings.

Conclusion
In summary, our project has achieved significant scientific and technological advances in the field of quantum photonics. By developing a scalable, integrated platform for quantum light generation, we have addressed key challenges in quantum state control and established a robust foundation for practical quantum applications. The intellectual merit of this work lies in its innovative theoretical and experimental contributions, while its broader impacts are reflected in enhanced educational opportunities, strengthened research infrastructures, and promising prospects for technology transfer that will benefit society at large.
